Dynamic Web 1: Command Line

Command Line

In the nutshell, the Command Line provides you with the means to control your entire computer from a little window called the Command Line Interface on your computer. Terminal is the software that hosts your Command Line Interface, and Xcode Command Line Tools are what permit you to do your magic within the Command Line. There is so much underneath the hood when using GUIs to get around your computer that you miss. The Command Line reveals all.

Where Terminal/CommandLine Lives

To launch Terminal, all you need to do is go into your Spotlight Search in the top right of your computer screen, click anywhere on the desktop, and hit the space bar on your keyboard. The Apple menu bar will then appear, and all the way to the right you will find a magnifying glass icon (aka search icon). Click the command key on your keyboard and then the space bar again. Spotlight will pop up. In the Spotlight search bar, type Terminal, and it will pop up. Click on the Terminal icon, and it will launch. You're good to go!

Accessing The Search Bar Directly

You can simply hover over the top right of your computer screen, and the Apple menu will show up with the magnifying glass/search icon right there. Click on the search icon, and type Terminal. When Terminal appears, click on the first icon that appears in the list with the word Terminal next to it, or hit enter, and an instance of the window will appear. You are good to go!

The pwd command

The first thing you probably want to do in Terminal is to find out what directory (aka folder) you are in. Type the following command in Terminal and then hit the enter key: 
pwd

pwd stands for print working directory. It prints out the directory that you are in.

pwd

When I type pwd in Terminal, the following is printed out to the Terminal console:


/Users/mariacam

Terminal is telling me that I am in the home directory on my computer.

Breaking down the Terminal window

Remember the little squiggly line which I called tilde (~)? (~) refers to the home directory. From whichever directory on your computer you are in, you can simply hit the shift key followed by (~) in Terminal, and it will take you to your home directory. Do NOT confuse (~) with backtick (`). They reside in the same key on the keyboard, but they are two totally different things. One is mostly used in the Command Line, and the other is used very often in JavaScript development. If you read the slide deck on Template literals, you know what I am referring to. To type a (`), you simply hit the key right below the esc key where (~) resides without hitting the shift key first.

Always have a space between a command and what follows it!

Even though Terminal commands may not be human readable words, they still should be treated as words, and words are followed by a space. So don't forget to make a space between a command and what follows. If you are executing the cd command followed by the directory you want to change to, make sure to make a space between it and what follows. Terminal will not understand it and will fail to execute!

the cd command

The cd command stands for change directory. To change directories, type cd followed by the path to that directory. For instance, if I want to go from my home directory into a directory on my desktop called desktop-folder, I would type the following in Terminal and then hit the enter key:


~/desktop/desktop-folder

Then, if I type pwd, the following will print out to Terminal:


/Users/mariacam/desktop/desktop-folder

mkdir command


mkdir foldername
mkdir followed by the name of the folder you want to create, creates a new folder within the current directory you are in. Whenever you create anything, whether it be a folder, file, etc., make sure that you actually want to place the file or folder within that location.

Creating two folders at once with mkdir

If you want to create an assets folder that contains an images folder, in order to do so, you have to type the following command and then hit the return key:


mkdir -p assets/images

This will create a new folder called assets with a folder inside it called images. However, you cannot create these same two directories at once without -p. Known as the -p switch, -p creates a parent directory in which a subdirectory(s) can be created at the same time.

The touchcommand

The touch command creates a new file.


touch index.html

touch index.html creates a new index.html file in your current directory.

The ls command

ls stands for list files, and it does just that. It will list all the files AND directories within your current directory.

Terminal (iTerm2 + ZSH) Syntax Highlighting

The result of executing the ls command results in pink and white. The pink indicates files, and the white indicates folders. Syntax highlighting depends on which Command Line Interface program or theme you are using, especially if the Interface has been customized. The image in the previous slide represents the Terminal program along with a customized ZShell, aka ZSH.

The ls -a command

The ls -a command lists all the files and directories in the current directory, AND all the (.) files and directories. (.) files are hidden files, and can only be seen with the ls -a command. They are not viewable in the Finder GUI, and it takes a lot of effort to find out whether there are any hidden files or folders anywhere at all.
